Fear of the Dark: 'Race', Gender and Sexuality in the Cinema (Gender, Racism, Ethnicity)


Publication Date: December 24, 1995 | ISBN-10: 041509710X | ISBN-13: 978-0415097109 | With A special thanks to "wetworx12" - The bitter, race-baiting troll who inspired this upload | filetype: pdf |



Studies of the portrayal of black people in film have tended to be studies for the ideological correctness of the depictions of black people and the extent to which they rely on stereotypes. By closely examining films such as Sapphire (1959), Leo the Last (1969), Black Joy (1977), Playing Away (1986) and Mona Lisa (1987) and situating them in their historical and social context, Fear of the Dark develops a particualar critical perspective on the film portrayal of black female sexuality and questions the extent to which black film makers have challenged stereotypes.


[b] Review [/b]
`What is particularly refreshing about (Lola Young's) approach is the determination to avoid big theories (trendy postmodernism a definite no-no), and instead to concentrate on historical context and material reality, which is, after all, what most people live by. Cultural studies at its best.' - Roger Sabin, IKON

'...adding her own important insights to forge an analysis which draws upon an array of cultural studies perspectives ... Young extends and adds to the field in dealing with British feature films.' - Social Semiotics --This text refers to the Hardcover edition.

[b]About the Author [/b]
Lola Young is a former professional actress and currently is Senior Lecturer in Media and Cultural studies at Middlesex University.
